>>9642142
it's kind of like translating Japanese to English. Shit is like a one to many situation all of the time simply because Japanese doesn't have a lot of ways to skin a cat (especially when compared to the nightmare gobblrfuck that is English) and so you could probably take a script in Japanese, give it to 5 different translators, and get 5 different translations, depending on all manner of things. Likewise, from a single blurry texture you could get 5 different interpretations by artists.

It's the problem of having to define one answer to an open question. It's like when gunpei yokoi defended using a black and white screen on the game boy. He said that if you draw two circles on top of each other on a whiteboard and say "it's a snowman" then people will fill the gaps in their mind of what the snowman looks like. Ask one artist to draw a detailed snowman to be "the" snowman in this, and someone observing it will say that it's not what they had imagined.

This is why movie adaptations of books can often seem off vs .the originals, because you read them and have an idea of what the characters look and sound like, all for it to be torn up when you see the Hollywood version where one team of (hopefully) interested people decided what every character and element would look like and would sound like and forced it upon everyone else.
It's also why Bill Watterson fought tooth and nail against merchandise for Calvin and Hobbes; He never wanted to get to the point of making a movie or tv show and having to decide what Hobbes' voice sounded like. That was for the reader to decide as they enjoyed the comic for themselves.

tl;dr a remake can basically never change graphics in any way without potentially alienating someone because there are too many ways to take something vague and turn it into something specific and inevitably, someone will like their own interpretation of it better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9647029
Of course it's not THE worst. There was an astounding amount of shovelware by that time and there's no shortage of contenders for the absolute worst. But all those awful games were mostly unknown. They weren't attached to an expensive license, they weren't printed by the million and they weren't bought by the vast majority of the userbase. E.T.'s not the absolute worst in terms of its playability but in terms of negative impact on the industry it might be #1.

You have to consider the context. The gaming market was oversaturated and becoming something of a circlejerk with every console selling the same arcade ports. And the quality control, especially when it came to the 2600, could be very lax. What the industry needed was something to revitalize consumer confidence and make them feel like plunking down the equivalent of $100 or more in today's money for a new game wasn't just a roll of the dice.

And E.T. was a chance to do that. It was a console exclusive with a huge brand name attached to it and a major marketing push. People understandably expected at least a passable game. Something the kids they bought it for would enjoy for at least five minutes before getting bored or frustrated. And instead they got a game which was technically functional and had at least kind of unique but not really fun or intuitive gameplay. It was a 'wtf is this' moment for everyone the first time they played it. And again, this was THE game of Christmas. "Well It's not top 10 worst of all time" isn't remotely good enough under those circumstances.

And keep in mind this was about the same time Atari horribly and inexplicably botched 2600 port of Pac-Man came out as well. The message from both these games was "we're not gonna try that hard anymore because we're pretty sure you're giving us your money anyway." They dared people to put the games down and do something else, and much to their surprise, people did. An epic miscalculation all around.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There were many many worse Atari games. Thing is, those other Atari games that were worse were random obscure or budget crap. I remember playing a game by Johnson & Johnson that was a thinly veiled advertisement for their products disguised as a crappy breakout clone. I remember an A-Team game that has pretty much nothing to do with the series and was just a re-skin of an earlier game that also sucked.

Thing is, those were obscure budget games, many that weren't even really sold at retail.

E.T. was a huge movie at the time, a major IP, and this was well before it was well known that licensed games tended to suck and before internet or even many gaming magazines. It was basically as close as a massively hyped AAA game as you can get, like Tears of the Kingdom, or Hogwarts, or Elden Ring, or God of War Ragnarock.

This would be like the equivalent of those games ending up like Sonic 06, Superman 64, Balan Wonderworld, or even Big Rigs considering it's clearly rushed nature.

It was a Christmas release too, so that added fuel to the "Worst game ever" fire, not to mention it was one of the first examples of such a massive bomb in the gaming world. It wasn't just because it was a horrible game, there was indeed worse, but it was a massively hyped and anticipated game of an at the time massively popular children's IP that was released for Christmas during a time when people would not have had the hindsight of licensed games usually being poor or internet/much magazines to warn them.

>And keep in mind this was about the same time Atari horribly and inexplicably botched 2600 port of Pac-Man came out as well

Wasn't the story behind that one that it was basically a not-even-alpha tech demo just to show that Pac Man could be possible on a 2600... and then Atari basically went "Good enough programmer, we won't pay you any more money to put more time into this, ship it"? There are homebrew versions of Pac-Man on the 2600 that are miles better.

I remember a detailed webpage by some guy who actually took it upon himself to patch E.T. to be a lot more playable. It was crazy to read how since he was only able to hex-edit the ROM and not able to disassemble it to change the actual source, any code he replaced has to take the exact same amount of time to process since the CPU manually outputted the video signal and changing the timing would completely mess up the image, parts he had to optimize to make it run faster so he could add new instructions that overall then took the same amount of time as the original code altogether, and scouring the rom to find handfuls of bytes to squeeze it all into.

http://www.neocomputer.org/projects/et/

It's a bit of an inbetween.
The game isn't bad, it has quirky dark humour tipical from late 90's Japan, it has a distinct PC game graphic style from the time.

The thing that usually attracts people is the nature of the world itself, how adorable Cookie is that triggers in some people some kind of parental instinct to protect her from this dumb world she finds herself in, the music is really good and catchy and it's overall a charming experience.
I wouldn't call it a hidden gem, but it IS an interesting game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9646847
It means you compose four 8x8 pixel images into a 16x16 pixel image, referring to each of the four as linear index like 0, 1, 2, 3.

So for example, metatile 0 might be made of
0: 1,2, 8, 9

where 1 refers to the image of a flower, 2 some grass, and 8 and 9 dirt.

I started messing around with some tiles as a test. I made some ground tiles, some random background objects, and a couple platforms. The bigger platforms are intentionally made in a way that they can be stretched out into large platforms. I'm not really sure what scale we're working at, so I tried to keep it generic. There's a huge difference between something like Mario Land and Mario Land 2 (ie the mushrooms and blocks were a single 8x8 sprite in the first game, but a 16x16 metasprite in the sequel).

I'm also not 100% sure what the standard 4 colors we're using are. I know GB Studio requires foreground sprites to replace the lightest color with a lighter color for the sake of indicating transparency, so I also did that here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP here, the current workflow I'm testing out uses the following:

- A tileset image of 8x8 pixel tiles using only rgb colors 0, 85, 170, 255, with 8 rows and 8 columns for a total of 64 tiles
- A Tiled tileset made in Tiled (free program) using this tileset. Just import and save.
- A Tiled tilemap using this tileset. This one defines the metatiles. Just arrange them how you like, but I like 8 rows and 8 columns of 16x16 pixel blocks. 64 metatiles is the max in the current scheme.
- Then your level as a tilemap, importing the tilemap above as a tileset of 16x16 pixel tiles. This should be one gameboy screen in dimensions, then expanding horizontally or vertically.

Tiled is a really nice editor. I think we could use it for enemy and item placement too.

posts.com:
>>9643979
I love it. I always have.

You must play it two player with someone who likes using the vehicle you don't use. Lot's of teamwork involved and it's very hard. Tons of weapon power ups, and deplete-able sub-weapons.

Lots of enemies and they come in fast. Hardly any slowdown. Good soundtrack, gritty 80s arcade graphics transport you back into a futuristic cold-war era.

Helicopter can dodge ground enemies, tank can dodge flying enemies, both can't dodge their shots. Helicopter can move all over fast, but can only shoot straight. Tank moves slower, and has to dodge/jump ground obstacles, but can fire in diagonal front directions.

No other game is quite like it, certainly on the SNES. It's been getting more popular, as it should. It is definitely one of the best co-op SHMUPs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Capacitors are known for being leaky on the original XBox, check if inside of yours stinks and has dried goop on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Bad caps on Xbox do cause some bizarre issues. One example for me was controllers working intermittently. I plugged/unplugged the controller too many times and a cap popped in front of my eyes (with the case off).
Replacing the main caps on Xbox is an easy solder project for a beginner so I would recommend it.
Check your cable as well though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
idk much about racers ne we liked them desu but RR4 pulled me in i guess aesthetically. heard the theme and gave it a try. the aesthetic is cool, the tracks aren’t crazy, but do have a nice feel, i especially love the three night time stages. the interfaces, menus, music, and character portraits all have this energetic yet still laidback feel, captures that cowboy bebop or ray crisis combo of badass action with lively jazz going on. the drifting is easy and intuitive, i like how especially as a beginner you can catch on quickly, however the levels get more punishing of your mistakes. just as gilbert says by the end you’ll be trying to run the perfect race. speaking of gilbert one thing that really set R4 apart from every other racing game for me were the stories they’re nothing too deep, but they’re fun, simple, and the two middle ones, ESPECIALLY the PRC story do enough to grip you just enough to add a story motivation to the fun gameplay. that’s what captured me, but lll expose myself and say i’m a complete outsider. hydro thunder, NFS: HP, GT II, Wipeout, TOCA, i don’t play any of those shits, so maybe R4 is just the most accessible in that way. oh and most of the OST kicks ass

TLDR: cool ass menus, music, simple but serviceable characters, easy to learn, somewhat difficult to master gameplay, but im less than a noob to racers, so take it with a grain of salt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's so weird. For the most part Mega Man X3 has the most nothing, bland level design of the SNES games. But then all of a sudden there's this part in the Giant Dam stage that might be the pinnacle. It can be tackled in so many ways depending on what you have:
If you have nothing you can't take the main path since the current is too strong, so you have to go through the tunnel below, which is full of spikes, holes and turtles.
If you have the ice weapon and the arm upgrade you can make an iceberg underwater and ride it to the surface to get the item on the left.
If you have the H mech you can either use its jet to get the item on the left, or kill the turtles and go destroy the giant propeller, which lets you climb the wall to get the item on the right or go down avoiding the corridor full of spikes.
Once you got either of the items, you can also skip on the water surface to get the other one. But if you killed the turtles, which is likely if you destroyed the propeller, they become obstacles floating on water that make the traversal more difficult.
Brilliant design. It's a shame that there was nothing else like it in the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Both are great
The GCN library is way the fuck deeper than the N64
It was also an era where Nintendo was doing a bunch of weird and interesting things with their IPs, so you got stuff like Metroid Prime, Mario Strikers, Luigi's Mansion, WarioWare and then new IPs like Pikmin and Eternal Darkness
On top of that you got Animal Crossing and Fire Emblem representation in the west, and significantly better third party support over the N64.

So to me it's like, yeah if I picked the top 5 games of the N64 to go head to head with the top 5 games from the GCN, the N64 would probably come out on top. But the sheer weight of the GCN's library pretty handily puts it on top over the N64 overall.

It's funny though I've been a Gamecube supporter since it launched, I bought FE: Path of Radiance and Paper Mario TTYD on launch, I was one of the poor bastards who had to wait an extra month to play Twilight Princess because I wasn't super interested in the Wii. So take that all into account when I say: I think the recent deification of the Gamecube is a massive over correction. It was an awesome console at the time and I don't think it deserved to be as eclipsed by the PS2 as it was, but holy FUCK do people put it up on a pedestal these days.

>>9633014
I got SM64 Christmas 96 and OoT in fall of 98 with my allowance, so yes I was there. I'm not saying they're bad games, I'm saying from a more objective perspective they aren't revolutionary. Virtually no games copied the SM64 camera frankly a good thing, everyone was copying the Quake and Tomb Raider cameras instead and things evolved from there. Z-targeting in OoT was a nice evolution for melee, but that's all it was. Z-targeting without movement was already in Megaman Legends, and Z-targeting with movement was already in Tomb Raider, so all OoT did was adapt it for melee with relative direction inputs. Again, a nice evolution, but obviously not revolutionary.

N64 was my favorite console since 1996. However I’ve been playing the Gamecube a lot since last year and noticed that a lot of the N64 games I loved have Gamecube sequels and ports, some better some worse. Let’s look at the list of the best N64 games:

>Ocarina of Time
- Ported, with a bonus master quest version
>Majora’s Mask
- Ported
>Mario Kart 64
- Sequel (Double Dash) is better
> Super Smash Bros
- Sequel (Melee) is better
>Goldeneye & Perfect Dark
- Timesplitters 2 is almost as good, plus you get Timesplitters 3 and you also get 5 James Bond games
>Rogue Squadron
- sequel is better
>Super Mario 64
- sequel is not as good, good enough though
>San Francisco Rush
- ported

Anyways, you pretty much get an at least decent followup, if not better version, of every great N64 game.

On top of this you have, with a Gameboy Player, access to 3 Gameboy generations, and through that ports of the best NES and SNES games (and that’s not even counting the compilations)

And on too of all that, you get RE4 and Metroid Prime 1&2

I can’t believe I’m saying this, but the Gamecube really is the better console. The amount of Zelda, Resident Evil, Sonic, Mega Man, and Mario games you can play on that thing is just mind blowing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The N64 probably has the most overrated library relative to the actual quantity of good games (or even total games) out of any console. There are entire genres that are unrepresented on the N64. But the few games it did have were well-made, and it had the advantage of more than 3-4-player multiplayer without requiring a multitap. And I say this as someone who had an N64 over its competitors during that gen.
The GameCube probably had some of the most creative, expertly crafted games of the era, or any era. It has way more variety than the N64, but some of the sequels to N64 games aren't as good (Mario Sunshine, Star Fox Adventures & Assault) though some sequels are considerably better (F-Zero GX, Paper Mario TTYD, Rogue Squadron 2). It had a decent amount of new IPs and third-party support (Baten Kaitos, Lost Kingdoms, Gotcha Force, Cubivore, etc). But a major complaint against the GameCube is how many games required extra peripherals to make the most of the experience (GBAs & link cables for FSA and FFCC multiplayer, broadband adapter for PSO and LAN support in Mario Kart and Kirby Air Ride, mic for Odama and the later Mario Party games, bongos for Donkey Kong Jungle Beat and the Donkey Konga games).
Overall, I prefer the GameCube.

People still go with the cap meme but I don't really believe there's anything particularly wrong with 65nm fats starting with CHECHJ. Percentage wise compared to launch power consumption is like 65% for 65nm fat, 42% for original slim with the 40nm CPU and 65nm RSX, and 36% for the 40nm RSX in most slim and super slim models.

Rather than some of the other meme shit people buy for PS1 and PS2 games it seems like there should be a market for BC fats modded with 40nm RSXs at this point, but that's getting to be the opposite of what this thread about because PS3 BC is ass for CRTs in most cases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9639518
So I went and tried it out side by side, both with the same composite out > VCR > TV chain and switching back and forth between AV1 and AV2, and the aspect ratio is the same, the PS3 is slightly lower for some reason (this just comes up because I was lining them up in TT's options menu and I had to go -1 on the PS2), and at least in TT some static screens like the Sony Computer Entertainment America Presents screen shake like a bastard but that's probably a CPU emulation issue I guess? The general thing though is that even in the XMB this PS3's composite output seems to be slightly sharper in principle, but generates rainbow artifacts like a motherfucker. Even with the Cross Color Reduction Filter in the options enabled specifically to tone it down there's noticeable red/blue bleed on black to white transitions that doesn't happen on PS2. I'm thinking they're outputting a more raw picture on purpose to try to make small text and stuff for HD games more readable on outdated displays at the cost of being ugly on TVs that aren't good at fixing it themselves.

tl;dr, my PS3's composite output is gross. But playing PS2 games on PS3 with component seems like it would be daijoubu.

I don't think that's strictly true. On PS3 it depends on the game and whether the developer set up support for 480p/i rendering. If they didn't, then yes, it gets downscaled from 720p, just as it would get upscaled to 1080p if that's not supported. In practice, IIRC, earlier games had 480i support whereas later games didn't bother because standard/enhanced def was mostly a dead meme by that point.

NTA but do you have any recommendations from personal experience? Because everybody cares about and documents the converters the other way around, but never the HDMI *to* composite ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641885
I have been milling about looking at various converters, the only good ones tend be from smaller hobbyist shops that are annoying to acquire easily.

Say you serious and are building a media PC dedicated for a CRT i think the best way to go about it is start with an older AMD GPU(15 bucks on ebay) that has DVI-I or VGA outputs then to converter then to your TV. The reason to use an older AMD GPU is because theres a driver on windows that will do resolution switching between 240p and 480i modes and all sorts of various CRT related settings that makes things work more authentically. This is an almost essential feature when dealing with an an older retro emulator machine because sprites start looking blurry without the proper 240p scanlines

HDMI does not play nicely with CRT from various CRT groups ive read, i think its because theres a floor of how low of a resolution HDMI can go down to which fucks with pixel scaling or some shit. Its just something to avoid whenever possible.

>How does Arcade games on a CRT work?
Perfectly fine.
> is there any limitations on what you can do on a consumer CRT in terms of arcade resolutions?
If it is a 24hz or 31khz arcade game then you will need a CRT that supports those resolutions. Something like a multisync monitor from NEC or Mitsubishi. 31hz is widely supported on basically any PC CRT monitor since it is similar to 640x480 vga.
>Can you even rotate consumer CRTs to play TATE without damaging them?
Yes, no problems.

LCD and OLEDs do not usually have a glass screen. So there would not be "glass in front of glass". There would be only one layer of glass.
And yes, it would help in a number of ways including adding contrast to the image and diffusing the light produced by it in a way that could be potentially flattering. Have you never seen an arcade monitor under smoked (not tinted) glass? Have you ever heard of the term micro-contrast?

But yes, aesthetics are the main goal here. To mask the edges of the 16:9 screen in a more sophisticated way. To have something that looks nice in a game room. These could be very large sizes, you know. Much easier to work with this than a 40" or larger CRT.
Using an OLED the image quality would be outstanding.
>burn-in
Please. We can be better than that with the baitposting and FUDing about that.
We all know that it is not a real issue for anyone who plays a good variety of games for a reasonable number of hours per day. Or maybe microLED one of these days.

>>9647927
n64 only outputs s-video at the highest, so if you want that, then sure, get something with s-video in. you could also rgb mod the n64 or use a clone console or a mister or something to get rgb output (any cable that plugs into the back of the back of the n64 is working with s-video to start out with, even if it outputs rgb). if you do get rgb output, then you can (probably) rgb mod the tv you have already. you might even be able to s-video mod it since it has the vcr. not sure, i only took a cursory look at the service manual. pvms (sony or otherwise) sometimes have rgb in, but not always. usually at least s-video (y/c) though. pvms do have a sharper picture than consumer sets, and that might make a difference sometimes, but anything over 600 TVL won't make a difference if i'm doing my math right based on the n64's 773.5 dots per line. that's probably higher than your tv, i don't see it listed in the specs. it doesn't matter that much anyway. the biggest factor is the input. composite to s-video is the biggest jump in quality from personal experience. no matter what input you use though, the fact is that the n64 only outputs 240p. things like a framemeister can upscale the video signal but upscaling can't add detail, only diminish it. if you really want to be able to see things better, then emulate and render at a higher resolution.

That's so cool. Those don't have any kind of video inputs and only tune into to channels broadcast over the air, unfortunately those are no longer broadcast since the switch to DTT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_terrestrial_television) so it won't pick up anything. If you have a NES or SNES and an RF cable you could try to hook it up to both VHF leads at the back (even barely touching should transmit a signal), put the NES/SNES switch on channel 3 and then tune on the TV knob into 3.

You turn the TV on by turning and increasing the volume like on old radio sets.

>>9621925
>It can take on a physical form, manifesting as weapons, armor, or sentient beings. The Maverick Virus behaves like an actual virus, spreading through physical space.
The Maverick Virus mutated from the Wily Virus, which was based on the Evil Energy that Wily found in Megaman 8.
According to Duo in MM8, the Evil Energy is actually a sapient alien substance that absorbs evil within robots minds and then multiplies as to infect more robots. Dr. Light found out that performing a full analysis of it was impossible (much like Zero's system). An entity made out of pure energy is an interesting concept since it can be a power source, be translated into electrical signals (and be transmitted as a virus) and even be converted into mass. Due to this method of replication, the original source can only be harnessed by beings of pure evil. The Wily virus made from it probably works in the same manner, "absorbing" Zero's destructive programming when he fought Sigma and had the migraines, and then spreading to Sigma and the rest of the reploids. Only someone who's pure evil could have it in their system and not die from it (like Wily in robot form).

That's why the Maverick Virus is so unorthodox and can do shit normal computer viruses can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the plot of X4 put plainly.

Repliforce was created to supplant the need to combat Mavericks due to the growing number of riots and rebellions perpetrated by Sigma and the virus, which the Hunters could barely control on their own, as evidenced in the past three X games. Repliforce's purpose was shown to be inefficient, and the Hunters were itching for a reason to disband them. Sigma noticed this, and began orchestrating the Sky Lagoon incident.

Magma Dragoon was a Maverick Hunter and prideful warrior who's always envied X's superior fighting abilities, believing the latter always hend back whenever they sparred during training sessions. This grudge he harbored against X allowed Sigma to convince him to sabotage Sky Lagoon and become a Maverick, all so he could force X to have a real fight with him, no holds barred. Still, Dragoon's motivation to betray the Maverick Hunters wasn't enough to cause the Repliforce war, as that would come later.

When the Sky Lagoon crashes, X and Zero find evidence of Repliforce presence in the rubble. They also find Colonel investigating the crash site, who claims to be looking for his sister Iris. The Hunters immediately demand him to surrender his weapons and follow them to the Hunter base for questioning (which often ends in imprisonment or decommission for Reploids, as someone has to take the fall until the real culprits are found, if ever. After all, the Maverick virus scare is a good enough prerogative to let the Hunters point fingers at just about anyone despite their own general ineffectiveness). The Maverick Hunters immediately grow suspicious when he refuses - the image of the second-in-command of Repliforce being detained would ruin public opinion on Repliforce and basically guarantee its dissolution through vox populi.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625818
The Hunters then demand General to disband the Repliforce and turn himself in for inquiry. Years of experience fighting Mavericks fueled the Hunters' concern that Repliforce could become dangerous, should they become infected by the Maverick Virus or grow strong enough to overpower the Hunters themselves.

The Hunters had a solid reason to be worried, but their authoritarian "do as we say or else" attitude was a big fucking insult to a man like General. Before the incident took place, Sigma warned him that this would happen sooner or later, as human beings were growing wary of armed Reploids running around (though General did not recognize Sigma during their meeting, since everyone thought he was dead for good). Sending a Repliforce representative to talk it out with the Hunters wouldn't work, since the Hunters wouldn't even give Colonel, General's right hand man, the time of day. General then decided that Repliforce should simply leave planet Earth and build a reploid colony in a space station. It wasn't a declaration of war so much as a "you don't trust us, so we're leaving" statement. The Hunters, of course, regarded their disobedience as Maverick behavior, and then the fighting began. The "Final Weapon" was originally the space station they wanted to move to, and was only turned into an actual weapon after the Hunters started going after Repliforce.

Even after the war begins, Repliforce officers like Jet Singray were shown evacuating the civilians before carrying out orders to destroy certain locations. Storm Owl's brigade was attacked by the Hunters, including X, who found himself acting just how Sigma wanted him to, when he denied Owl's accusation that the Hunters were corrupt, before executing him with a charged shot to the face.

Meanwhile, Double was sent by Sigma to Hunter base as to disrupt the flow of information and prevent any chance of peace accords between Repliforce and the Maverick Hunters from happening. And so you have Megaman X4.

>>9628239
Putting it into order it goes like this:
>Evil Energy -> Wily Virus (EE + robot reprogramming algorithm) -> Maverick Virus (Wily Virus optimized to explot Reploid design flaws) -> Sigma Virus (Maverick Virus fused with Sigma's digitized AI at the end of X1) -> Zero Virus (Sigma Virus fused with the virus smuggled by Dynamo into the Eurasia space colony and Zero's AI) -> Nightmare Virus (Zero Virus + DNA Program successfully reverse-engineered by Gate) -> Copy Chip (DNA Program of Sigma and many other old Reploids rendered inert and implemented into New Gen Reploids as to make use of the abilities it grants users)
It may sound silly in a work of fiction, but do remember how many strains of COVID we've gotten in like 3 years.
Putting this into perspective, EE being a sapient entitity does lend to the idea that it keeps consuming hosts and evolving much like a virus, jumping from robot to robot, system to system, mechaniloid to mechaniloid, iteration to iteration. Given the X series' overarching theme of robot free will, it does seem like the virus itself is acting on its own free will in a very twisted way, by rending others of their own.
If Wily turning himself into a cyborg holds true or at least plausible, the virus may have even taken over him. After all, his real body was never found. It may even hint at the reason why X and Zero are not allowed to go near the locations where their capsules were found.

The older 2/3/4-in-1 cards from the 90s had additional storage, but you could only move/copy saves to them from their own Action Replay-like menu, when a game was booted they just functioned like a 4MB RAM expansion, not as a memory card. The more recent ones you get today can function as a real memory card... for those 82 games.

>>9647685
The Saturn is a great console to get if you like arcade perfect (or close to) 90s fighting games, shoot 'em ups, arcade style racing games, weird but excellent JRPGs, interesting versions of games better known on the PS1, and quirky arcade deep cuts. If that sounds good than you'll have a good time, but don't get one expecting it to be a PS1 but kinda different.

The internal differences between hardware revisions is negligible. Japanese Saturns are generally in better shape than US ones, and the gray (model 1) or white (model 2) colors look really nice. They're also significantly cheaper.

Get a Japanese Saturn imported, find a cartridge with PseudoSaturn Kai firmware on it, and you'll be able to play pirated copies of games you have burned to CD. Accessories to consider are a save cartridge (if your PSK cart doesn't have direct saving), a 3D controller (a Saturn controller with an analog stick), and an arcade stick if you're into fighting games or shooters. The PSK cart you get should have 1MB and 4MB RAM support, so you don't have to get a dedicated RAM cart (RAM carts are extra memory that is required for some games, similar to an Expansion Pack for the N64 only not as faggy). Most of the games that utilized the RAM carts were Capcom 2D fighters, but there were some others (the port of Metal Slug uses the 1MB cart, for example).

Check the /vr/ wiki for recommended games, or post what genres you're into and we can recommend some.

gl;hf and don't forget to bully the bernieposter about the time he complained on /adv/ about his wife refusing to have sex with him but forgot to turn off his tripcode whenever you see him post.

if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

>>9625207
>never do nighttime crashed UFOs
i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing so you don't have to worry about bringing them down, and if you're worried about night missions you can usually wait a few hours before actually sending your skyranger in.
i usually don't even consider shooting down ufos until i'm confident my main base(s) can handle an attack, i have plasma beams and the aliens start spamming more missions, maybe they're infiltrating germany and i don't want half a dozen ufos tanking my score during a particularly bad month, or maybe i'm being cheeky and i want to nuke a terror ship in january or something. ymmv

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9631206
>i'm not nearly as experienced with tftd so i can't really provide input on it
It's generally similar with the following important differences

>aliens will do shipping route attacks starting in April--these can have any alien race on them
>artifact sites will start appearing in July--these are always a Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew, and you cannot duck out of them due to a massive point penalty (-1000 points for failing to complete the mission, -3000 for ignoring it).
>the game will generate 12 artifact sites, one for each region of the globe
>colonies are always Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew in part 1 and Lobstermen in part 2, but the race that constructed the colony will send supply ships to it
>on lower difficulty settings you will get more port/island attacks and fewer shipping route/artifact sites
>in infiltration missions, none of the alien infiltration fleet lands--until you get advanced craft weapons you will not be able to shoot down most of the USOs
>the TFTD terror ship (Battleship) has more powerful weapons than the battleship (Dreadnought) so while you could easily shoot down a EU Terror Ship with two Interceptors+Avalanche missiles, it's extremely risky (but still possible) to attempt it in TFTD--since it also never lands, the only way to fight one is to shoot it down
>in base defense missions, up to 5 aliens will spawn inside your base
>the Barracuda has shorter range than Interceptor and can't fly as far before running out of fuel

another little pointer is that when fighting landed or crashed UFOs there's a certain probability that aliens will spawn inside the ship or outside of it. this depends on their rank, but generally:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9631206
>i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing

https://www.ufopaedia.org/index.php/MISSIONS.DAT

Most UFOs on most missions land except during retaliation. Small scouts only land during base construction or harvest missions (small scout #1 on harvest missions lands, #2 doesn't). The first terror ship on terror missions does not land either. Shooting a UFO down of course may spawn a retaliation mission, which is a 50% chance of occuring either in the region the shootdown was in or the region where the X-COM craft that shot it down is based. If a retaliation scout passes over your base, it may become revealed to the aliens, and the odds go up the more facilities the base has.

If you shoot down the Battleship attacking the base with an X-COM craft, or they don't find your base at all, the retaliation mission ends. If the aliens do attack and you beat them in a base defense mission, the retaliation mission is immediately restarted with a new Small Scout and they'll keep going for it until they fail to find your base or you shoot down the incoming Battleship. if you shoot it down with base defense weapons it produces the infamous bug with endlessly attacking Battleships.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638543
If you're fighting a Battleship, the commander is on the bridge and will usually be carrying a Blaster Launcher, although early game it's more likely Heavy Plasma. In alien bases he always carries Heavy Plasma and will be in the central command room, though on Superhuman he'll spawn outside someplace due to lack of spawn nodes and it can be real hard to identify him without a Mind Probe.

Weapon loadouts for base defense missions are same as the Battleship, meaning the commander will likely have a Blaster Launcher, although he can spawn anywhere and again be very hard to identify without a Mind Probe. It's generally easiest to capture one from a Battleship as you can guarantee he'll always be on the bridge.

Note that you will also need a live alien leader to complete the research tree for Cydonia or Bust.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Battleships are easy to clear since you can just shoot up the central grav lift at aliens above and if you have Blaster Bombs, you can also fire them up there. Beware that aliens will fire Blaster Bombs down the grav lift at you as well. In the original games you could shoot a ranged weapon up the lifts to easily pick off aliens on the floor above you, but OXC makes it that the aliens can also shoot down the lifts at you which they used to not be able to do.

Also note the room I marked with an X. That room has a spawn node, and the large-sized terrorists (Reaper, Cyberdisc, and Sectopod) can spawn in there and get stuck and unable to leave. For the latter two you can be in for a nasty surprise when you go into that room and one of them is in there and facing you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You'll want to eventually get psionics, and the best way to do this is to bag a Sectoid leader from a larger UFO. Of course he'll be mind raping you the entire mission but...about mind control. It depends on line of sight. The aliens can only target soldiers they can see, and they'll always attack the weakest soldier that is visible to them. This is why different soldiers will be targeted at different times.

When you have a Psy Lab built, you can put up to 10 soldiers in it to train them, but this will take a month during which time they're effectively out of action (you can still use them on missions but why are you putting them in harm's way?) At first you just want to determine what soldiers have good psionic strength and which ones are crap. The good ones you may leave in the Psy Lab for additional months to build their psionic skills while the shitty ones can be used against non-psionic aliens. Or you can just take them into action and practice on aliens--each attempt at mind control counts towards your psy skill; doesn't have to succeed, just the attempt is enough. While taking over Floaters and Mutons is easy, the tougher aliens need a much stronger team.

When you go to Cydonia, make sure all soldiers have a minimum of 60 psionic strength and really, you want 80 or more.

The problem is that the tech tree in TFTD is bugged.
If you don't research certain items in a specific order, the game becomes unwinnable as you will not be able to unlock essential techs required to win the game.
To compound matters, there are two different versions of TFTD with slightly different tech trees (and different bugs associated with them).
It's positively rage inducing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I used a map editor to check and it turns out the map packs for OXC have all the alien spawn nodes intact so aliens should spawn in your base in TFTD properly. Maybe I just got a weird randomizer roll the last time I did a base defense. Also guess what else? The OXC map packs changed the tile properties to get rid of bugs that let you grenade aliens through UFO outer hulls.

https://www.ufopaedia.org/index.php/Explosions#Hacking_HE_versus_Walls

Basically, the walls in question here (anything not a north or west wall) originally had their "Block" value set to 0 so although you cannot actually destroy them short of a Blaster Bomb, they do not block explosions. OXC's map packs simply set their "Block" value to 100 to remove this exploit.

Some glitches in the TFTD maps were also fixed for example you used to be able to blow up USO entrance doors with a Sonic Pulser but their armor value was changed to 80 (the max damage a SP will do to terrain at the epicenter of the explosion is 60).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9649684
Initially, there was just Fatal Fury and Art of Fighting. KoF is a crossover between SNK franchises: Fatal Fury, Art of Fighting, Ikari, Psycho Soldier / Athena, as well as new original characters (that later became more important). You don't have to play older games to understand newer ones, though it enhances your experience.
Art of Fighting 1-2 are pretty whatever Street Fighter 2 clones. AoF3 is an unusual mix of Virtua Fighter / Tekken-like mechanics with standard 2D fighter gameplay. It's rough around the edges but has nice graphics. Those games are really mostly for fans only.
Fatal Fury shares universe with Art of Fighting, but has different heroes. Starting from 2, it plays like Street Fighter 2, but with planes system. Real Bout series introduced easier combo system. The highlights of the series are FF Special and Real Bout FF 2 or Special.
Garou is a "new generation" of FF, it removes planes but adds parrying and a few cool but hard gameplay mechanics. Also has great graphics. One of the most recognized SNK games beside KoF.
KoF is a crossover game, however the FF/AoF chars don't play any roles in the plot. KoF has its own lore, and it is more complex than the old games; it has 4 arches—Orochi saga (Kyo and Iori fight to seal the demon Orochi), NESTS saga (K' vs Kula and an evil org that cloned Kyo), Ash saga (French twink stole powers from Kyo / Iori / Chizuru for his evil plot), and Verse saga (the last one in kof XIV-XV).
KoF has its own, distinctive gameplay. It's like Street Fighter, but adds fast hops and movement, making the gameplay much more aggressive and rushdown-heavy. KoF has been the biggest SNK fighter, it's the most fleshed-out one. 98 or 02 are generally recommended, they have respective updates called Ultimate/Unlimited Match that add some characters and rebalance the games, as well as updating the systems. which one you prefer is up to you. Other KoF games tried tag (2003-XI) and assist (99-2001) systems.

>>9647503
Total hyperzoomer opinion. In the 90s-2000s, you shipped a final game, and if it lived up to the sales expectations, the expansion pack you were already doing prelim work on didn’t get canceled. In the before times, if you shipped a game with a bug, you had to risk destroying your reputation and also incur huge costs by mailing out a fix to everyone who bought a copy. When the internet penetrated enough of the market, devs realized they could just put patches online for people to download—it was low cost and still an honest thing to do. It wasn’t until the late 2000s when (((developers))) and (((publishers))) figured out you could use digital distribution to ship broken/incomplete games, charge people $80 upfront, and then make them sit through “day 1” updates to play games for which they’d already paid. And then from there it was literally just a sleazy hop and jump to realize you could charge people $80 for half a game and sell the other half in 2 parts for $20 each, many months later. Add addictive grugbrain gambling on top of that and you arrive at AAA gaming in 2023. Give me CDs and shareware any day…

>>9647503
Bugfixes were frequently done separately from expansions, in fact often being available without the expansions.
Expansions also were not all EA style "let's cut a piece out of the finished game and then sell it later", in fact I'm unaware of any examples from the day. That said, that's not all DLC ever made either.

Expansion packs may or may not be planned ahead, or based around "This was an idea we thought about implementing, but there wasn't the time to realize it, or we needed to retool it to work." but there's nothing shady about revisiting an unrealized idea or even finishing or retooling something cut during the game's development.

>>9647591
Often the case, also. Games which bombed didn't tend to get expansions. I think there's a few cases, but not very many.
In fact, games which continued to do well and had well received expansions could get additional new expansions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9649897
Not sure about majority, it definitely varied.

>SC Broodwar
>AoE2: Age Of Conquerors
>Wolf3D : Nocturnal Missions
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny
>DN3D : Atomic Edition
>Ultimate Doom
>Doom 3 : Resurrection Of Evil
>Extreme Rise Of The Triad
These were done in-house by the same devs.
Something like Ultimate Doom is like a quasi-expansion, the intent being that since Doom 2 was going to be a retail product instead of a mail-order one like the first game, if you were buying Doom 2, you could also grab the first one and get the full experience in one go, and there was a new episode of levels to give it more of a point. If you already had the mail order version you could get it upgraded to the retail version for free.

>HL : Opposing Force
>HL : Blue Shift
>Diablo Hellfire
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny Pt. 2
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny Pt. 3
>Quake : Dissolution Of Eternity
>Quake : Scourge Of Armagon
>Final Doom
>Master Levels Of Doom
>DN3D : Nuclear Winter
>DN3D : Duke It Out In D.C
>Duke Caribbean : Life's A Beach
These are ones developed by other devs in part or in full. For the Duke ones, NW is trash, D.C is ok, and Caribbean is excellent, all three were made by the same team at Sunstorm as I get, possibly with the exception of a level designer.
The Spear Of Destiny sequels are trash garbage, and FormGen did some stuff which iD didn't know at first, being forced to change it. Master Levels were like a crude handpick from submissions opened for the purpose (included Maximum Doom, a shovelware disc very much like the Wizard Works ones), while Final Doom was 50% a fan level pack which iD bought the rights to, and 50% two disgruntled brothers who worked on it making a chance offer to iD.
Hellfire, famously, were a third party making an offer to Blizzard, which the devs of Diablo largely REALLY didn't want, but didn't really get any say in. It's made in part from leftover dev assets already in the retail game's files, which were much nicer than Synergistic's own.

I don't like that I can't get stats naturally and have to go out of my way to properly strengthen my characters. For example, HP is something that goes up when you take about half of your life in damage during a fight, and strength/hit count goes up by swinging your weapon. At a certain point, I'm going to go before any enemies and kill them in one hit, thereby never taking damage again, so my HP will stay in the double digits for the rest of the game. A lot of the stats are like this, where you will never normally be in a situation to gain them just by playing the game so if you want to improve them, you wind up metagaming like beating down your own characters to get HP/defense.

It kind of reminds me of X-COM in this way, if I wanted to train my reactions stat on there I would need to purposely put my characters in a situation where they know there's an enemy ahead of them and they don't outright kill it, instead letting it fire at them first so they can make a reaction shot against it. Or intentionally killing soldiers to make my permanent ones panic to train their bravery stat. My soldiers never get those stats on their own, it's only when I set up a specific scenario to improve them does it occur.

>>9650531
he Nyko Airflo PC controller was made for Windows 2000 and is compatible with Windows XP. Currently there are no drivers available for this controller. But you can try installing the driver in compatibility mode. Download the driver for Windows 2000 and follow the below steps to run it on compatibility mode.

Right click on the setup file of the driver and select Properties.

Select Compatibility Tab.

Place a check mark next to Run this program in Compatibility mode and select the operating system accordingly from the drop down list

Let the driver to install and then check the functionality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sengoku Rance was the biggest for me.
I played it when I was about sixteen, never having really played an "adult" RPG before, and it totally redefined in my mind what an RPG could be.
Compared to other games in the series it's quite tame, but for a teenager, playing a game where messing up means that a character you love might get raped or killed was almost overwhelming.
What makes it special I think is that those elements aren't just there for shock value; they're building blocks of a legitimately great story.
Each of the elements― the huge stakes; the sweeping scale of the journey; the incredible amount of freedom you have; the intensely beautiful, beautifully intense soundtrack; rock-solid, legitimately challenging gameplay; and Rance, who is one of the greatest and most interesting characters in fiction― all combine and build upon each other. By the end of the game, it felt like every decision I made could change the fate of a nation and a world.
More than anything, it stopped me from ever again looking lightly upon a game just because it has porn in it. After finishing Sengoku Rance and wanting more, I was lucky enough to experience two equally incredible titles: first CROSS†CHANNEL, then Saya no Uta, and after that there was no stopping me. I would eventually go through the entire translated catalogue of the Japanese adult scene, then start learning Japanese while playing the then-untranslated Rance VI, leading to me studying to be a professional translator today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Initially watched my older brother play FF 4 and 6 on the SNES as well as Chrono Trigger, however I remember also seeing bits and pieces of Secret of Mana and probably some others I've since forgotten. When he returned home from college, we had just gotten a Playstation 1 and he saw the paltry number of games I had and wanted to show me Final Fantasy VII (as well as MGS). Needless to say, I was impressed and loved it. However, it wasn't long before I saw ads for FF8, and he wasn't around to show it to me (I think he skipped it initially as well) so I jumped at the chance to get it and to this day I love it with all my heart. I'm taken straight back to being 11 years old and thumbing through the Bradygames strategy guide, learning all about the game, inspecting the bestiary, etc.
After VIII though, I dropped off. I tried Legend of Dragoon and beat it with my dad but we both agreed that shit went on for way too long. I skipped IX because I was a dumb kid that wanted mature games for mature gamers and the kid-like appearance of the characters wasn't my jam. I did give X a try but I was ready to drop turn-based JRPGs and did. Got gifted XII and XIII and they did absolutely nothing for me. I was done.

Sadly, I totally missed out on Dragon Quest games and all the more obscure JRPGs. They just weren't put in front of my face so I never engaged with them. I could go back and play them but I don't know. The last new turn-based rpg I played was Octopath Traveler and while I mostly enjoyed my time with it, by the end I was skipping every cutscene. I never even did the optional hidden boss Galdera.

>>9647340

I think the game has some decent looking sprite art and animation. Nice use of gradients and dithering. Who owns the rights to Awesome Possum? I feel like WB Games might? Tengen was a subsidiary of Atari Games, and Atari Games was the arcade division of the original Atari. Atari Corp. released the Jaguar. Tengen was mostly notorious for making unlicensed games on the NES, and the Tetris thing. On the Genesis/Mega Drive, they were one of the first Sega licensed 3rd party publishers. I thought their Hard Drivin'/ Race Drivin' ports were good. The framerate never bothered me. Tengen did have some good arcade to Genesis ports . They did help sell the machine as an arcade system, and even published a few Japanese developed games in the west. A few sports games... Awesome Possum was them jumping on the Sonic bandwagon. Right beside Bubsy. The character Awesome Possum is almost like a tongue in cheek to Sonic. With the badguy being names Dr Machino.

>>9642587
Arbok gets glare, which is at least interesting. Plenty of options for poison for blue, not missing out. Sandshrew however is the best ground type pokemon in gen 1. Unless you go for speed abuse dugtrio. Cubone is solid too, but you get sandshrew earlier and it's better, so the winner Blue

Gloom getting petal dance makes it one of the best grass types in gen 1, weepinbell gets razor leaf, it's trash. Winner Red

Primeape is 2nd best fighting type in the game, getting one early in the game can be nice, persian is also possibly the 2nd best normal type, and has crit abuse and a great movepool so Tie.

Arcanine has fat stats, Ninetales has a few interesting moves, both fire, not really missing out over the other here another Tie

Pinsir vs Scyther, well, neither provide a counter to psychic. If we allow wing attack from yellow into play Scyther is the clear winner, otherwise its mostly a tie, but Id still edge scyther the winner since gets swords dance and such. So Red

Electabuzz and magmar both do the same thing. Just electric vs fire. I can't really call a winner here, so another tie. You don't get them in the same place, which is also interesting. One is in an area part of the main story, the other is not, but no major flaw or advantage on either.

Ultimately, red wins. I'll point out, if you want a grass type and you pick charmander or squirtle and play blue, you're fucked on grass, because bellsprout really sucks, petal dance vileplume is way better. Basically, scyther and vileplume clinch it for red. It's actually pretty balanced how they split it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think its interesting how all three starters have different playstyles that all manage to have different pros and cons so that none of them truly feel hard if you play different ways. even beyond the "Bulbasaur resists the first three gyms, Charmander is weak to the first 2(possibly 3 if you grind him to Charizard before Lt. surge)
Bulbasaur is great for defensive and stat changing/stalling play. Just the fact that he reissts a lot of common types and has a big spongey HP makes him perfect for the typical G1 grind method of "weak Pokemon first turn, then switch". also has a surprisingly high Special/attack, which means it can hold its own.Just solid for learning game mechanics.
Squirtle is a nice balanced middle ground between defense, special and attack, learns the biggest variety of moves and can cover most types buy itself.
Charmander feels the easiest to grind with because so much of what you encounter are bug types and Pokemon witha weak special stat ; while his attack/special aren't actually higher than the Bulbasaur line his move pool centers more around stronger attacks early on. Feels geared towards players who just want to use damaging moves.

You can beat the game largely with just one of any of them, sure, but I'd say Bulbasaur is the easiest to build a team around early on, Charmander is good for grinding through the early game if you just want to muscle through with attacks until you can take advantage of mid game Pokemon that become available, and Squirtle is best if you largely want to focus on one -three Pokemon. But you can easily use Charmander to solo the game, or Squirtle to build a team around.
Personally, when I want to not use a starter I usually go with Charmander to grind through with ember, get a nidoran as a support until I can lean more on him and get to Cerulean and have access to all the Pokemon around there.

The robots in megaman classic do have self-awareness and emotions, but what separates them from Reploids is the fact that they cannot act upon what they perceive and feel unless programmed to. Wily has to modify them into acting erratically and dangerously.

Light noticed this and thus began working on X. Is it canon? No, but it makes sense. Even our current-year primitive AI experiments eventually develops its own ideas that skirt the limits of what it's allowed to do, it's not far fetched.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9650909
the mechs are the main focus of the game, but the point remains that it isnt like every mission the game always spams mechs. it simply doesnt happen that way. I think that the ground units are useful if used properly. but the game does a bad job at explaining any of it. one robot seems roughly equal to or outweighed by 3 or 4 artillery trucks for example, which can shoot very far. also mechs dont go underground which is where the complaint about spam would make more sense but in relation to tanks.

game has a slow pace but it isnt that big of a deal. despite how slow it seems at times, because of the games 3 tiers of battlefield it still ends up feeling fast paced regardless even when it is slow.

armored fists are better than axes. rimtech doesnt have the strongest melee gear. you need to give them the HTH legs as far as i know to match milagros damage. thats part of the game balance. If rimtech had the most powerful melee weapons they wouldnt have the HTH legs. armored fist is viable TLDR but is better with HTH. you can also use HTH and then research hammers.

>>9649656
No, I do inded. The timbre of a particular sound synthesizer, be it a single digital chip, multiple chips, or a collection of analog oscillators, filters, etc, etc is not a "soundfont". Soundfont is a proprietary format used by sample-based playback engines (typically MIDI) to provide alternate, or additional sets of samples. The sounds a synthesizer makes are timbres, patches, or otherwise just "the sounds a particular synthesizer makes".

>>9649549
- 50 to 150cc
- Every single Cups
- 3 Star Ranking

>Several factors account for a hidden score, which then translates to a rank:
>The more coins collected, the higher the score.
>The player's time on each lap. Points are awarded depending on the time and are never deducted.
>The more times and longer players hit the brakes, the lower their score. This does not count if players brake to avoid a slip from a Banana Peel.
>The more times and longer players let go of the acceleration button, the lower their score.
Using Triple Red Shells, Stars, and Lightning Bolts decreases the score, with the Star decreasing the score the most.
>If Lakitu must pick up the player, the score is lowered. Initiating the mini-turbo at the correct time will negate it somewhat, however.
>The more times players hit enemy racers or obstacles, their score is lowered. Hitting walls slightly decreases the score more.
>Getting hit by items lowers their score, except for Lightnings, which increase the score.
>The more retries used, the lower their score.
>The more time the player spends outside the track, the lower their score. THIS INCLUDES THE SHALLOW WATER IN THE BEACH COURSES AND THE MUD PUDDLE IN CHOCO ISLAND 2.
>Starting the race with a boost increases the score.
>Initiating more drift mini-turbos increases the score.
>Passing an item box while already having an item (but not deployed yet) increases the score.
>Picking certain characters can also affect the score, giving bonus points. This is because some have less grip on the road than others, so the game rewards characters with the least grip the most points.
>Bowser (45 points)
>Wario, Donkey Kong (40 points)
>Mario, Luigi (30 points)
>Princess Peach, Toad (10 points)
>Yoshi (0 points)

i was in an atari st club back in the day. one of the guys walked in and just started handing out free STart magazines and he said that it was going to be the last one ever published. he knew one of the guys who worked on the magazine.

apparently, the story was that STart ran an article that was slightly critical of some aspect of the falcon or something like that. tramiel called the magazine and chewed out the editor and the editor supposedly shot back that, without STart, there was no press for atari anymore and that tramiel was giving them nothing to work with and the magazine was constantly losing money. he told tramiel he was ending the magazine and that was that. no final issue or anything.

i always wondered how much of that was true. anyway, sure enough, i think it was the last issue (if i remember correctly, it was a guy holding a floppy disk or something).

i really miss computer clubs and pre-internet computing in a way...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9649586
For 30+ years, playing a video game was seen as a challenge to overcome and get better at. The same as playing a sport, or completing a puzzle.
Didn't matter if the game was dumb faggot anime kawaii ~uguuu shit, some super trenchcoat edgelord shit, or anything in between. It was expected that unless you were playing a game intentionally designed for toddlers, that it would carry some amount of challenge or difficulty.
Over the past 10-15 years the industry has been overtaken by "experiences" that see the actual act of playing the game as a necessary burden, and now people are overwhelmed that playing a video game may actually require you to do anything than mindlessly consume it.
Jap games, due to having no rental market, and the home player base overwhelmingly preferring easy and story driven games would often have their difficulty altered in western releases to make them harder, with some notable exceptions like Square who would do the opposite and make their games even easier

>>9650731
play against people.

if you just want to beat the AI, backdash until you are at the edge of the screen, then when the AI runs forward to get close to you, dash in, 1+PG, 66P. (surprise exchange followed by dashing elbow, it throws them out of the ring) You can even do 466PK (body check) or 66KK (double jumping kick) if you want to feel fancy, or even 66K -> 466PK if you want to cover extra distance. Note, when doing the body check, if you wait a few frames between the 466 and the PK, you'll cancel a dash into the body check which is useful for covering more distance.

AI is always vulnerable when dashing forward, which you can abuse by doing throws whenever they do. For example with Jacky, you can dash back, and when the AI runs forward you do 664PK to dash forward and do the Trip Hammer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9650807

Yes, some people do. Those people have unrefined taste and they like smooth edges more than they like the various qualities that are lost when this filtering is performed. Jagged pixels look ugly to them, simple bilinear filters look blurry, and CRT shaders seem to add unnecessary distracting noise. They want smooth cartoons that look clean. This image does not provide that (for example, the blackboard's lower edge is still a sawblade for some reason) but many normal people think that fewer sharp edges means more betterer quality even if there are still some sharp edges remaining.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9647960
>I heard that apparently the triology release is missing some effects due to the motion controls, such as the beam overcharge animations.
>Is there a list of those missing effects anywhere (are any of them missing from Prime 2?), and does the remaster include them?
In Metroid Prime, when you charge a beam, you have effects. The most noticeable one is the ice beam, and the arm cannon freezes over. These effects are not in Trilogy for whatever reason. I've always thought that they were able to, but if you read ahead to the part on MP2, they didn't make it perfect, so the ice beam freeze would clip in and out and look weird, so they just removed it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=46ODgZaxGqU

The water ripple effects are also changed for whatever reason, but I don't really notice that because that's not as common as charging your beam. From my years of reading about it, apparently its due to porting the game to the Metroid Prime 3 engine and dealing with some of the physics there. These effects are remade in Remastered. Just search for a video and look at them charge Ice beam.

Metroid Prime 2 also has charge beam effects. These effects are still in Trilogy, but not perfectly ported. You probably won't notice.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VJ-G1iOV6OE


>Does the M+KB hack run on the original prime 1/2 release or triology?
Primehack is a version of Dolphin that adds KB+M controls when emulating Metroid Prime. Both GameCube and Wii versions are supported.

https://github.com/shiiion/dolphin/wiki/Frequently-Asked-Questions#what-versions-of-metroid-prime-are-supported


>Does it also enable dual analog input on a controller?
You can use dual analog controls too.

>>9644460
>>9648710
Some characteristics of cinematic platformers include:
*Human characters will have realistic proportions, unlike the super-deformed character designs that u see in games like Mario Sonic or Crash where they’re all huge headed manlets.
*Many of these games had their character animation done by rotoscoping, some would call it the motion cap of back then.
*Characters cannot instantly stop moving or instantly accelerate to their maximum walking or running speed; it takes time for them to slow down or speed up. They also can't do an instant 180 degree turn.
*Characters have a maximum jump height that is almost the same as real life, unlike (again) like in Super Mario or the like where characters can jump exaggeratedly higher than their own height. This means that the way to get to higher places may involve climbing stairs, climbing ropes, or climbing ledges, since simply jumping there is not an option.
*A long enough fall can and will kill ur playable character.
*Characters cannot change their direction of movement while in the air, they’re stuck facing the same direction until u land down and then turn manually.
*In combat, both the player and enemies will use weapons or melee attacks, instead of cartoony gameplay mechanics like let’s say Goomba Stomp or Collision Damage.
*When the player character picks up an item, the game will show that the character reaches for it and picks it up with his/her hand, like how Joel and Arthur from Last of Us and Red Dead 2 respectively have to complete an animation of them picking up an item. By contrast, items in other platform games tend to disappear when the player collides with them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9650732
Other typical features of the genre include:
*The game screen will have little to no user interface elements, such as points, time counters, level numbers, character stats, etc.
*The gameplay is usually by tradition linear, especially compared to that of Metroidvanias.
*Typically, screen panning is used instead of scrolling. The camera will be fixed on a particular landscape and remain static until u go out of bounds to either side or from top/bottom where the camera will then pan to a new fixed position and this’ll go on every time u reach a new edge of a spot in the game world.
*Although these games often feature action sequences, which often include one-on-one combat, their gameplay also includes level exploration and puzzle solving.
*Characters generally parkour.
*Characters have to draw their weapon first before being able to attack, and then their movement is limited until they withdraw it.

Anyways tl;dr I know but long story short I think Ico does indeed meet some of these requirements to be able to be labeled as a cinematic platformer (never thought I’d see one in 3D, there’s the story of Oddworld and how they fucked up their own play style cuz they didn’t know how to cinematic platform in 3D, but that’s not thread related I guess)

posts.com: There's a weird debate about this game ongoing for the last twenty years and people just sort of talk past each other about it. People like it because it's calm and contemplative, and sort of like the gaming equivalent of listening to ambient music. It's atmospheric and the simplicity of the gameplay and flawed controls/extremely minimal HUD is questionably a feature rather than a defect. I don't really care much about the technicals, I just like it because i like wandering, and the expanse of the game gives the sense of a believable but foreign world--like a waking dream. If you find the controls irritating to the degree that it makes you question why people like this, that makes sense to me too. It's just a matter of preference.

I'm gonna hypothesise Soulsbourne games wouldn't exist without SOTC.

It's like all FromSoft did was add enemies between bosses and some RPG shit in, and there you have it, Dark Souls. Everything else, the vague mysterious abstract plot, the gameplay that essentially boils down to boss rush with sequences of exploration in between, overall weeb-but-western melting pot art direction, etc is strongly paralleled.

Only reason I don't really like either of those series is because I never liked boss fights, boss fights are always my least favourite part of any game; but other than that I respect what they did. SotC deserves respect as a pioneer of a lot of modern gaming trends, but like all pioneering games it looks weaker in retrospect.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9638734
>>9641319
The only similarities I can see are that they're fantasy games with mysterious plots and depict the ruins of a Western civilisation with a kind of alien feel to it. King's Field IV came out first and already had a weird, bleak, interconnected fantasy setting with strange and depressed NPCs scattered around that all had lines that would fit seamlessly into any Dark Souls game.

The nature of the mystery elements is also pretty different, in SotC things are mysterious because you're told almost nothing about the setting, whereas Souls games have a ton of flavour text and dialogue containing cryptic references to figures and events you have no context for, almost begging you to try and connect the dots. In SotC you're hardly given any dots to connect.

Even then I think you could argue this mystery element wasn't quite as strong in Demon's Souls anyway and only really took off in Dark Souls. If you just want to say that SotC inspired them to switch to third-person, maybe, but in that case I'd argue SotC's contribution was pretty minor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My guess?

Some exec either looked at the box art and went "What is this baby stuff? Boys won't be interested in this!" and had an artist to make a new cover based on screenshots or having them play the game for about 10 minutes.... or without even looking at the cover or game an exec just had an artist just look at screenshots or play the game for about 10 minutes and make a new cover.

Back then games were seen as toys for little kids and nobody gave a shit about the original story, what is considered canon, or even the original designs. Look at the abominations in Captain N.

In some cases they would intentionally alter it to make it more "American", because they thought whatever they came up with would sell better, or because they thought the original Japanese version would not appeal to customers in the US. Again, nobody cared about the story or canon of these "little kids toys" back then so they didn't put two thoughts into completely tossing the original version aside and making up whatever they wanted in it's place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Put yourself in the perspective of a marketing department in the 80's, in a less globalized world, the only anime kids would know are some imports like Voltron or the three series of Robotech, more cute stuff like Hello Kitty is niche.
Kids are selfconsious about cute and kiddy things, game graphics are still thought as being representational than literal(it was only a few years since home consoles were atari; no one thought the characters were meant to be literal big lobs of pixels or that the cars were literally all single colored chunks). People saw the Megaman graphics(and name) and didn't think he was literally meant to be some tiny kid, but a cool cyborg man.

>LA is a superior game to LttP in every way.
Arguably true. I love LTTP a lot, but I think my favorite is the Oracle games, because they're like LA but far more vast and comparatively more challenging. Played them for the first time a year or two back when recovering from surgery, and fuck me, they were so much better than I ever expected.

>Wario Land is just a hard game to play these days. I don't mean like it's difficult or bad or anything, but it's like playing a game for babies. There's no challenge and even the secrets are super obvious.
Heh, well, it's not particularly hard, no, (though I'm pretty bad at most platformers) but I find the game irresistibly charming for its overall design and character. I love Wario as the anti-Mario, greedy, crude, violent, two-faced, he's really just in with whatever he does for making money so he can live in great comfort, he's not noble at all and he's not ashamed of that.

The first Wario Land gets it so well, fucking with Mario didn't really pan out, but hey, what if he besieged that pirate den island to then rob those fuckers for every penny and pretty trinket they've got? They're crooks, he can't get in trouble with Mario for that, right? This makes it yet better that Wario Land 2 starts with said pirates breaking into his castle when he's sleeping to rob him of the money he robbed from them (also flooding his basement), and thus begins his quest of getting back his stolen-stolen shit.
Wario being this absolute lout preoccupied with money makes him a lot more fun and interesting to me than Mario, and they figure that out even with the gameplay itself, Wario being less about jumping on top of enemies, and instead bumping them over to pick up and throw them, or giving them a running/jet assisted tackle sending them flying out the level. Optionally groundpounding them flat with his big ass, which slams down with such force that the earth quakes for a split second.

>>9637434
Plenty of reasons to play DX

- colours that look good for the most part (the counter example provided above isn't enough to dismiss all the other parts of the game that look good)
- extra dungeon with good fights (was it 2 or even 3 bosses?) and good puzzles. Entirely made of new graphics and new enemies, so it's not just lazy rehash shitty dungeon like so many ports have (Final Fantasy GBA games, Chrono Trigger on DS, etc)
- Extra tunic if you want them. Note that you can very well ignore them: play through the entire colour dungeon, beat the final boss, and exit through the front door without picking up either tunic.
- Photograph quests that adds new cutscenes that in some cases help build identity for characters that lacked it, and the photo graphics are comical and full of soul

Meanwhile all the anti-DX have against the game are:
- a choke full of stuff that DX itself didn't start and which is also true found in this or that version of the original.
- "it looks bad", usually trying to "prove" it by focusing on minor details nobody had noticed when playing like >>9637205. And even if you don't like the colours, guess the fuck what, you can play DX in black&white. So that doesn't hold either.

Link's Awakening was my first Zelda, I had one of the non-DX European version. After I discovered DX there was no reason to come back to it.

I have no idea why the internet is so intent on shitting on DX. Usually people will pull up with a tons of shit for a bit "extra content" of dubious quality (again, those ports of FF/CT I mentionned). Here you have extra content that's actually original, true to the game and well designed; and instead people will go through lengths to use unfair arguments against the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In fact, the extra dungeon is designed in such a way that a first time player is likely to miss it completly without outside knowledge, yet someone who has already played the non-DX version or someone who's already played the game will pay attention to it
>what's up with this book? I don't remember this from the original game..
or
>what's up with this book? I completely missed it on my first play

Whereas someone playing it the first time is likely to see the book at the start of the game and forget about its existence.
It was made this way specifically to offer a bonus for replays and to offer a different experience than the first time with the tunics as a reward if you figure it all out.

So the only way you "ruin your first playthrough" is if you're looking up a guide; and someone who did manage to figure out how to get to the dungeon and beat it as soon as it's available, on his own, isn't likely to consider the reward "ruining the game".
